item.title: Netanyahu Seeks Immunity From Israeli Corruption Charges
item.description: His request to Parliament is a rare move, and a potentially unpopular one, heading into a general election. But it could keep the Israeli leader out of court.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner

item.title: Pro-Iranian Protesters End Siege of U.S. Embassy in Baghdad
item.description: Iran’s ability to deploy militias to attack the American Embassy, with Iraqi support, made clear how much power it wields in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Falih Hassan and Alissa J. Rubin
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Protesters gathered outside the United States Embassy in Baghdad for a second day on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Bet He Could Isolate Iran and Charm North Korea. It’s Not That Easy.
item.description: The president assumed economic levers would guide the countries’ national interests. Now, he confronts twin challenges in an election year.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: The Iranian-backed attack on the United States Embassy in Baghdad played into President Trump’s worries about American diplomats and troops in the region.

item.title: The Lesson of an Albanian Earthquake: The Balkans Aren’t Ready for the Big One
item.description: Successive governments have failed to address the risks posed by aging buildings and shoddy construction, leaving millions vulnerable.

item.title: Hong Kong Protesters Return to Streets as New Year Begins
item.description: Weeks of relative calm ended on Wednesday, as people marched in large numbers and the police deployed tear gas and pepper spray.
item.dc:creator: Russell Goldman, Elaine Yu and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: What Kim Jong-un’s Latest Threats Say About His Trump Strategy
item.description: With an election and impeachment trial pending in the United States, North Korea’s leader added elements of caution in his threat of “shocking” action.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un at a Workers’ Party meeting in Pyongyang, North Korea, this week.

item.title: How the U.S. Embassy in Iraq Became a Target
item.description: After months of turmoil in Iraq, U.S. airstrikes against a pro-Iranian militia drew a backlash.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Protesters outside the American Embassy in Baghdad on Tuesday.

item.title: Why the Fires in Australia Are So Bad
item.description: Bush fire season is nothing new to Australians, but this summer has been calamitous — and it’s far from over.
item.dc:creator: Andy Parsons, Russell Goldman and Matthew Abbott
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man on Tuesday tried to defend a property from a neighboring house already engulfed in flames in Lake Conjola, Australia.

item.title: Pope Francis Apologizes After Slapping Away a Clinging Pilgrim
item.description: As the pontiff greeted members of the public on New Year’s Eve, one woman grabbed his hand with both of hers. A video of the incident was shared widely online.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Vatican Media, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A combination of frame grabs showing a woman grabbing Pope Francis on Tuesday and the pope subsequently slapping her hand in admonishment.

item.title: Pika-Who? How Pokémon Go Confused the Canadian Military
item.description: “We should almost hire a 12-year-old to help us out with this,” an official wrote.
item.dc:creator: Mariel Padilla
item.media:description: A user playing Pokémon Go in Montreal in 2016. After the app was available in Canada, the Canadian Armed Forces issued a public warning, urging civilians to avoid military property when searching for Pokémon.

item.title: Zoo Fire Kills at Least 30 Animals in Germany
item.description: The blaze, which was reported shortly after midnight on New Year’s Day, burned down a monkey enclosure. Only two chimpanzees survived. The police said a sky lantern might have been the cause.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:description: Candles and flowers were placed outside the zoo on New Year’s Day.

item.title: Mexico Prison Fight Leaves at Least 16 Inmates Dead
item.description: Officials said several guns were found in the penitentiary.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: The men’s penitentiary of Cieneguillas, in the state of Zacatecas, Mexico.

item.title: Taiwan’s Top Military Official and 7 Others Die in Helicopter Crash
item.description: The helicopter was carrying military personnel to an event in northeastern Taiwan when it went down on a wooded mountainside.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Taiwan’s top military official, Shen Yi-ming, during a news conference in Taipei, the capital, in March.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Austria, Australia fires, 2020: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: Austria’s Kurz to Govern With Green Party in Unlikely Partnership
item.description: After months of negotiations, conservatives and leftists have agreed on a coalition that could set an example for the rest of Europe.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze

item.title: India Cold Wave Breaks Records, Shuts Schools and Makes Bad Air Worse
item.description: Across the north, including New Delhi, plunging temperatures have caused a run on shelters in a region more used to extreme heat.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Feeding seagulls in the fog on Sunday in New Delhi, on the banks of the Yamuna river.

item.title: Pompeo Cancels Ukraine Trip Amid Protests at Embassy in Iraq
item.description: A meeting with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine would have been the first for a top Trump official since the impeachment inquiry began.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, center, at Mar-a-Lago on Sunday with Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper and Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

item.title: North Korea, Iraq, Australia fires: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: Fazle Abed, Founder of a Leading Relief Agency, Dies at 83
item.description: Mr. Abed gave up a job as a senior executive at a multinational company to start BRAC after he saw his native land, Bangladesh, devastated by war.
item.dc:creator: Shalini Venugopal Bhagat
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Fazle Hasan Abed, the founder of the relief agency BRAC, in 2010. He won a number of awards for his humanitarian work.

item.title: North Korea Is No Longer Bound by Nuclear Test Moratorium, Kim Says
item.description: Kim Jong-un said North Korea was free of a self-imposed pause on testing nuclear weapons and long-range missiles, which President Trump had called a diplomatic victory.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, declared a halt to all nuclear and ICBM tests in April 2018.

item.title: Macron Stands by Contested Pension Plan, Despite Pressure From Marathon Strike
item.description: In his annual New Year's Eve speech, President Emmanuel Macron of France hinted there could be changes to his plan, though he insisted “fear shouldn’t mean inaction.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Martin Bureau/France 2, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France during his New Year’s Eve speech on Tuesday.

item.title: New Year’s Eve 2020: Pictures From Around the World
item.description: Confetti is flying as the new year makes its way across the globe.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Eckinger

item.title: Angola Freezes Assets of Ex-President’s Billionaire Daughter
item.description: Isabel dos Santos, called Africa’s richest woman, is one of three people accused of causing the state losses of more than $1 billion.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: Isabel dos Santos in New York last year.

item.title: Carlos Ghosn’s Escape: A Lawyer in Beirut, a French Passport and a Lot of Mystery
item.description: The prominent former auto executive eluded the authorities and the news media to flee while awaiting trial, setting off a flurry of speculation.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Michael Corkery
item.media:description: Junichiro Hironaka, a lawyer for Carlos Ghosn in Tokyo, addressing reporters there on Tuesday.

item.title: Japan Loves Robots, but Getting Them to Do Human Work Isn’t Easy
item.description: With a declining population and workers in short supply, Japan has fully embraced robots. But getting them to work to “the standard of humans” is often a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A robot picking up an artificial potato at Hokkaido Research Organization in Sapporo, Japan.

item.title: Merkel’s New Year’s Speech Calls for Action on Climate and Tolerance
item.description: The German chancellor, in her 15th such address, expressed optimism about the coming decade despite large challenges ahead.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said on Tuesday that future generations would “live with the consequences of what we do or fail to do today.”

item.title: Throw a Dish. Don’t Eat Lobster. What Are Your New Year’s Superstitions?
item.description: Across the world, there are many ways to ensure good luck: a kiss at midnight. A bowl of black-eyed peas, rice and pork. And, of course, swinging a flaming ball of fire to ward off evil.
item.dc:creator: Laura M. Holson
item.media:description: A person who kisses their beloved at the stroke of midnight will have 12 months of continued affection, according to one superstition.

item.title: French Chef Loses Legal Battle Over a Lost Michelin Star
item.description: Marc Veyrat was outraged when La Maison des Bois, his restaurant in the French Alps, was stripped of the guide’s top rating.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Elian Peltier
item.category: La Maison des Bois (Manigod, France, Restaurant)
item.media:description: Marc Veyrat in 2018, when his restaurant was awarded three stars in that year’s Michelin Guide. The 2019 edition downgraded it to two.

item.title: Carlos Ghosn, Fugitive but a Favorite Son, Returns to Beirut
item.description: For many residents, he represents the Lebanese dream, of leaving the country and becoming a success.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: A billboard campaign in Beirut in late 2018 expressed support for the former auto executive Carlos Ghosn, who was then being held in Japan.

item.title: A Couple Unwittingly Threw Away $20,000. The Dump Gave It Back.
item.description: The money, hidden in a box of possessions from a deceased relative, was returned thanks to a hawk-eyed (and honest) worker.
item.dc:creator: Anna Schaverien

item.title: Iraq, Carlos Ghosn, New Year’s Eve: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Thousands Flee to Shore as Australia Fires Turn Skies Blood Red
item.description: The country’s east coast was dotted with apocalyptic scenes on the last day of the warmest decade on record in Australia.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A kangaroo rushes past a burning house in Lake Conjola, New South Wales, Australia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Protesters Attack U.S. Embassy in Iraq, Chanting ‘Death to America’
item.description: President Trump blamed Iran after demonstrators breached the compound’s outer wall. Tensions are high after American airstrikes killed members of an Iran-backed militia.
item.dc:creator: Falih Hassan, Ben Hubbard and Alissa J. Rubin
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A protester holding an emblem from the embassy late in the evening.

item.title: Carlos Ghosn, Brexit, Cyprus: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in January
item.description: Our picks for January, including “Bojak Horseman,” “Uncut Gems” and “True History of the Kelly Gang.”
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray

item.title: American Airstrikes Rally Iraqis Against U.S.
item.description: Iraqi leaders say the United States violated Iraqi sovereignty with attacks that killed 24 people in retaliation for the death of an American contractor.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Ben Hubbard
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The headquarters of an Iranian-backed militia, Kataib Hezbollah, in Qaim, Iraq, on Monday after an American airstrike.

item.title: Bolivia Expels 3 Diplomats in Tiff With Mexico and Spain Over Morales Aides
item.description: The caretaker president accused the Mexican ambassador and two Spanish diplomats of breaking norms by aiding former officials linked to Evo Morales, the ousted president.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Police officers in La Paz, Bolivia, on Monday near the Mexican Embassy. Diplomatic tensions erupted when allies of Evo Morales, the ousted president, took haven in the compound.

item.title: Xinjiang, 7-Eleven, Hong Kong: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: ‘A Slow-Motion Chernobyl’: How Lax Laws Turned a River Into a Disaster
item.description: A look at 15 years of attempts to clean up Mexico’s most polluted waterway revealed that the country has neither the means nor the laws to preserve its environment.
item.dc:creator: Steve Fisher and Elisabeth Malkin
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: The heavily polluted Santiago River cascades into a waterfall and releases a powerful stench as it cuts through the town of El Salto, in Jalisco, Mexico.

item.title: Nicaragua Frees Political Prisoners After International Pressure
item.description: The release of dozens of Nicaraguan detainees came amid bolstered United States sanctions and criticism of a crackdown on hunger strikers.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:description: Neyma Hernandez, left, and Ivania Alvarez celebrated on Monday in Managua, Nicaragua, after being released from prison. The women were “aguadores,” taking water to hunger strikers.

item.title: Amid Balmy Winter, Moscow Trucked in Heaps of Fake Snow. A Blizzard Ensued.
item.description: Lacking snow to complete the holiday atmosphere, Moscow bought fake snow from skating rinks. “It will all create a festive mood, I am sure,” one Muscovite said.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A Christmas market on Monday in Red Square in Moscow.

item.title: Fireworks, Long a German New Year’s Eve Tradition, Are Losing Their Luster
item.description: Faced with the concerns about safety, pollution and potential damage to historic buildings, Germany is rethinking private fireworks.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Official fireworks will still take place in Berlin on New Year’s Eve, but private displays have been banned in some areas.

item.title: Inside China’s Push to Turn Muslim Minorities Into an Army of Workers
item.description: The Communist Party wants to remold Xinjiang’s minorities into loyal blue-collar workers to supply Chinese factories with cheap labor.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Austin Ramzy
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sudan Sentences 29 Intelligence Officers to Death for Teacher’s Killing
item.description: The ruling came just weeks after Omar al-Bashir, the ousted president, was convicted of money laundering and corruption.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Protesters with a picture of the teacher Ahmed al-Kheir outside a court in Omdurman, Sudan, on Monday.

item.title: Hanukkah Attack, John Lewis, N.F.L. Playoffs: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Woman Who Accused 12 Men of Rape Is Guilty of ‘Public Mischief’ in Cyprus
item.description: The British woman said that a dozen Israeli men had raped her in a resort town, and then retracted her statement. She could face up to a year in prison.
item.dc:creator: Lizzy Ioannidou and Iliana Magra
item.media:description: The British woman who was charged with public mischief, center, arriving at court in Paralimni, Cyprus, on Monday.

item.title: In Indonesia, Outlaw Gold Miners Poison Themselves to Survive
item.description: One large mining company is trying to shut illegal operations, which use mercury. The small-scale miners say there’s no other way to earn a living.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Adam Dean
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wildcat miners digging for gold near Taliwang, Indonesia. The illegal miners use mercury, a toxic chemical, to process the ore.

item.title: A 7-Eleven in Japan Might Close for a Day. Yes, That’s a Big Deal.
item.description: In a dispute captivating a country of workaholics, Mitoshi Matsumoto says the company is threatening to rescind his franchise after he complained about draconian work hours.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mitoshi Matsumoto, the owner of a 7-Eleven in Higashi-Osaka, Japan, wants to close the store on New Year’s Day.

item.title: China Sentences Wang Yi, Christian Pastor, to 9 Years in Prison
item.description: The founder of one of China’s largest unregistered churches was given a lengthy sentence for what the government called subversion of state power.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and Ian Johnson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Chinese Scientist Who Genetically Edited Babies Gets 3 Years in Prison
item.description: He Jiankui’s work was also carried out on a third infant, according to China’s state media, in a new disclosure that is likely to add to the global uproar over such experiments.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: The scientist He Jiankui at a medical conference in Hong Kong last year, when he announced he had created the world’s first genetically edited babies.

item.title: Ukraine, Huawei, Soccer: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: Left Behind by Migrant Husbands, Women Break the Rules and Go to Work
item.description: Wives are shocking their traditional West African villages by earning money and running large households while their husbands are in Europe seeking jobs.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Laura Boushnak
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Putin Thanks Trump for Helping Russia Thwart Terrorist Attack
item.description: The Russian president called the American president to thank him for a tip about an attack said to be aimed at St. Petersburg.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin at the Kremlin last week.

item.title: Climate Change and Political Chaos: A Deadly Mix in Honduras Dengue Epidemic
item.description: Rising temperatures are increasing the range of disease-bearing mosquitoes globally. But in Honduras, the effects are compounded by government dysfunction and criminal gangs.
item.dc:creator: Kirk Semple
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children being treated for dengue fever at a hospital in San Pedro Sula, Honduras.

item.title: Somalia explosion, Iran documents, North Korea: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: U.S. Launches Airstrikes on Iranian-Backed Forces in Iraq and Syria
item.description: The strikes were a response to a rocket attack that killed an American contractor.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Iraqi Shiite fighters from Kataib Hezbollah during a military parade in Baghdad in May.

item.title: Somali Terror Group Al Shabab Remains Resilient Despite Setbacks
item.description: The group suspected in a weekend attack that killed 79 people has lost territory, suffered defections and been targeted by increasing United States airstrikes. But it can still mount large attacks.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: The site of the truck bomb attack at a checkpoint in Mogadishu, the Somali capital, on Saturday.

item.title: Missile Strikes Military Parade in Yemen, Killing at Least 10
item.description: The explosion took place at an event for recruits to a separatist militia. Children were among the dead.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: A ballistic missile strike left a hole near a soccer field in Dhale Province, Yemen, on Sunday.

item.title: With Prisoner Swap, Ukraine’s President Inches Toward Peace With Separatists
item.description: Among those traded were riot police officers accused of killing protesters during mass demonstrations in the capital, Kyiv, in 2014.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukraine and pro-Russian separatists exchanged prisoners near a checkpoint in eastern Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: The U.N. Tried to Save Hospitals in Syria. It Didn’t Work.
item.description: Russian and Syrian forces have bombed sites on a flawed U.N. no-strike list with impunity. Relief groups are giving up hope.
item.dc:creator: Evan Hill and Whitney Hurst
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The destroyed entrance of a hospital in the village of Kafr Nabl, south of Idlib, Syria, in May.

item.title: Samoa Lifts State of Emergency After Deadly Measles Epidemic
item.description: The Pacific island nation will reopen schools after a measles outbreak killed 81 people, many of them children.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Johan Auvele, 3, got the measles vaccination this month from a Samoan health worker who traveled to his village.
